messages.text:
I am getting something really weird with `Matrix(sparse())`
I have a vector X, which I rearrange into a Matrix using `Matrix(sparse())`
size makes sense: 40*40 = 1600
most numbers of the matrix are what I expect, but a column is completely off, see how the maximum are different, which is weird since it's supposed to be the same data, just rearranged from vector to matrix?
```julia> size(X)
(1600,)

julia> Z = Matrix(sparse(x, y, X));

julia> size(Z)
(40, 40)

julia> maximum(X)
10.062613798887448

julia> maximum(Z)
19.08816683600714```

Matrix(sparse())

Matrix(sparse())

size makes sense: 40*40 = 1600
most numbers of the matrix are what I expect, but a column is completely off, see how the maximum are different, which is weird since it's supposed to be the same data, just rearranged from vector to matrix?

julia> size(X)
(1600,)

julia> Z = Matrix(sparse(x, y, X));

julia> size(Z)
(40, 40)

julia> maximum(X)

messages.text: When you make a struct as they do in `DiffEqOperatoers` like `struct CenteredDifference{N} end` only to define a funcion with the same name `function CenteredDifference{N}(derivative_order::Int,approximation_order::Int, dx::T,len::Int, coeff_func=nothing) where {T<:Real,N}...` that at the end returns a `DerivativeOperator{...}("arguments")` how should one interpret the type `UnionAll` when taking `::typeof(CenteredDifference)`? I am trying to dispatch on the type of the constructor, but I get an error since the type of all the different `CenteredDifference` eg. are `UnionAll`. Do anybody how to make this work?

messages.text:
I am unable to index into a 3-dimensional array with multiple cartesian indices:
```julia> A = rand(Int8, 3, 3, 3);

julia> A[CartesianIndex[CartesianIndex(1, 1, 1), CartesianIndex(3, 3, 3)]]
ERROR: ArgumentError: unable to check bounds for indices of type CartesianIndex{3}```
However this works when I remove the `CartesianIndex` type from the array:
```julia> A[[CartesianIndex(1, 1, 1), CartesianIndex(3, 3, 3)]]
2-element Array{Int8,1}:
 44
  2```
Any idea why this is?

messages.text: I am new, but not new to REPL's (coming from Lisp), and slightly confused about using the Julia REPL in a particular way. I have a package, which works correctly from the REPL and everything using Revise.jl, but I am not sure how to "put the REPL in the scope of my package". What I mean, is all functions from my package that I call must be fully qualified as `MyPackage.some_func()`, even after `using MyPackage`. How can I tell my REPL to switch packages such that I only have to issue `foo()`?

messages.text:
hi all. I wanted to understand the scaling performance of multithreading. Say I have a function which calculate the root of a function repeatedly:
```using Base.Threads, Roots, BenchmarkTools

nthreads()
# 16

function singlethread()
    for i in 1:100000
        find_zero(x -> x^3 - x^2, 5.0)
    end
end

@btime singlethread()
# 411.331 ms (2200000 allocations: 210.57 MiB)

function multithreads()
    @threads for i in 1:100000
        find_zero(x -> x^3 - x^2, 5.0)
    end
end
@btime multithreads()
# 68.632 ms (2200081 allocations: 210.58 MiB)```
So even though Iâ€™m using 16 threads, the scaling is only 5 times. Is this a normal behavior? If so, any chance I can improve the scaling like switching to `@spawn` or multiprocessing?

elements.text: hi all. I wanted to understand the scaling performance of multithreading. Say I have a function which calculate the root of a function repeatedly:

using Base.Threads, Roots, BenchmarkTools

nthreads()
# 16

function singlethread()
    for i in 1:100000
        find_zero(x -> x^3 - x^2, 5.0)
    end
end

@btime singlethread()
# 411.331 ms (2200000 allocations: 210.57 MiB)

function multithreads()
    @threads for i in 1:100000
        find_zero(x -> x^3 - x^2, 5.0)
    end
end
@btime multithreads()
# 68.632 ms (2200081 allocations: 210.58 MiB)
So even though Iâ€™m using 16 threads, the scaling is only 5 times. Is this a normal behavior? If so, any chance I can improve the scaling like switching to
@spawn
or multiprocessing?
